content:
How to find a way through a forest of scandals

ROBERT MUELLER toiled over his report for two years, slightly longer than it took Herman Melville to write Moby Dick. Mr MUELLER’s epic may be the most eagerly anticipated work in American literature, but though he passed it to the attorney-general, William Barr, on Friday March 22nd, it is unclear when or in what form it will be published. Both the president and the House of Representatives have called for the full version to be made public, but the attorney-general must weigh whether to redact parts that infringe the privacy of people it mentions or that reveal intelligence.

News coverage: Robert Mueller’s report is complete

It is not yet clear whether Mr Mueller’s report contains devastating new evidence against the president, whether it adds nothing to the record, or something in-between. Yet the hundreds of pages of indictments that have already been made public provide a tantalising portrait of the scandals surrounding Mr Trump. And Mr Mueller’s indictments are just part of a wider ecosystem of investigations into the president.

The overview is this. The Russian government was running an operation designed to “sow discord in the US political system” through social media from 2014 on, and well before Mr Trump ran for office. In the campaign Mr Trump had business dealings with Russia, specifically for a tall tower in Moscow. The Russian government knew about this, just as Mr Trump denied it. At the same time there were contacts between the campaign and people with access to emails that Russian hackers working for military intelligence had stolen from the Democratic National Committee (DNC).

On top of this are possible violations of campaign-finance law springing from a scheme to pay a pornographic actress to keep quiet; using charitable funds for uncharitable purposes; allegations of bank and insurance fraud; and, possibly, bending of the tax laws beyond breaking-point. When lumped together, each individual scandal seems less remarkable than it otherwise would—a reminder that Steve Bannon, once Mr Trump’s campaign chief, boasted of flummoxing the opposition by “flood[ing] the zone with shit.” The flood, however, seems not to have been a tactic so much as a characteristic of the world Mr Trump surrounds himself with.

The uses of history

One way to put his predicament into context is to compare Mr Trump with other presidents under investigation. This shows three things. First that scandals have a life of their own: investigators, Congress and presidents cannot easily control where they end up. Second that scandals often involve corruption among a president’s friends and associates, but that it is extraordinarily hard to pin their crimes on the man in the Oval Office. And last that Mr Trump stands out as the first president caught up in scandals that implicate a foreign power—and a hostile one at that.

The first independent prosecutor to look into a president’s affairs was John Henderson, whom Ulysses S. Grant appointed in 1875 to investigate allegations that whiskey distillers and public officials—among them Orville Babcock, Grant’s friend and private secretary—had conspired to cheat the federal government out of tax revenue. Grant was suspected of nothing more than excessive, perhaps even naive, devotion to friends and family (his brother-in-law helped two friends try to corner the gold market, sparking a financial panic). Though Babcock was acquitted and Henderson sacked, the investigation resulted in 110 convictions and recovered millions in taxes.

In the 90 or so years between Grant stepping down and Richard Nixon taking office, four other presidents parried with independent prosecutors. James Garfield and Theodore Roosevelt were both investigated over allegations of corruption in the federal Post Office, resulting in hundreds of convictions.

In 1923 Calvin Coolidge appointed a pair of special prosecutors, one from each party, to look into allegations that Albert Fall, the interior secretary, had taken kickbacks from oilmen to obtain drilling rights on federal land—notably a spot called Teapot Dome, in Wyoming, which gave the scandal its name. Silent Cal inherited this particular scandal after Warren Harding, elected president with the help of oil money, died in office (Coolidge was his vice-president). Fall was convicted for bribery and became the first cabinet secretary to go to prison.

In 1952 Harry Truman forced the resignation of his attorney-general, who fired an independent prosecutor looking into corruption in the Justice Department. But the Teapot Dome scandal was the apex of presidential malfeasance until Watergate, which also occasioned the appointment of two special prosecutors. On October 20th 1973 Nixon’s attorney-general and deputy attorney-general resigned rather than carry out the president’s order to Sack Archibald Cox, the first independent prosecutor, after he subpoenaed Nixon’s White House recordings. Sacking Cox began to turn public opinion against Nixon, who, like Mr Trump, viewed the Justice Department as an instrument of his will rather than affording it its customary measure of independence (which has only grown, by virtue of norms and policies, since Watergate).

The thing most people know about Watergate is that it was not the burglary that did for Nixon so much as the cover-up. That is true, but the break-in at the DNC headquarters was hardly trivial. The Trump-Russia scandals also centre on a break-in at DNC headquarters, making Watergate the best reference point when weighing Mr Trump’s scandals. Congress famously asked of Nixon: what did he know? And what did he do to cover it up?

For Nixon, the answer to the first was that he did not have advance knowledge of the break-in, but knew about it shortly afterwards, at which point he ought to have called in the police. Then came the cover-up: the use of the CIA to prevent the FBI from investigating; his attempt to present edited versions of his White House tapes as being complete, thereby obstructing justice and holding Congress in contempt. Those tapes also revealed that the president had been keen to set the Internal Revenue Service on his political enemies. Even after all that, only six of the 17 Republican members of the House Judiciary committee were prepared to back a resolution that the president had abused his powers.

Yet changes in America’s political culture in the following two decades would make those impeachment votes seem like a golden era of bipartisanship. Two prosecutors also investigated Whitewater, a failed real-estate investment that Bill and Hillary Clinton made in the late 1970s, when he was attorney-general of Arkansas. The first, Robert Fiske junior, lasted just six months before Ken Starr replaced him. Mr Starr’s investigation led to 15 convictions, and sprawled far beyond its original mandate, including into Mr Clinton’s sex life, a turn which ultimately led to his being impeached in the House for lying under oath, and then acquitted in the Senate. Mr Starr, working with the assistance of a young lawyer called Brett Kavanaugh, produced a voluminous report, which the House voted to make public almost immediately. That stands in contrast to the legalistic Watergate equivalent, which was made public only last year, 45 years after its completion.

The most striking feature of the investigations into Mr Trump’s campaign is that, unlike the scandals that came before, they involve a hostile foreign power. This matters, and not just because it opens up a question of whether people working to elect the president betrayed their country, either for money or in hope of gaining power or influence. It matters because the founding fathers drew up the Impeachment clause with precisely this sort of malfeasance in mind. Impeachment, wrote James Madison, would be appropriate if a president lost his capacity to do the job after being elected, if a president were to take bribes or embezzle money or, worst of all, if he were to “betray his trust to a foreign power”.

The Republic is less existentially vulnerable to external enemies now than it was in Madison’s time. But Russia does not aim to conquer democracies, only to degrade them; and had the eagerness of Mr Trump and his retinue to work with a foreign adversary been known before the 2016 election, the result might have been different. Justice Department practice cautions against indicting a sitting president, so the Russia affair poses little legal risk to Mr Trump while he is in office.

Yet the accusation that the president betrayed his trust to a foreign power is so serious that, if true, it would warrant Impeachment on the terms set out by Madison. Impeachment by the House and a conviction in the Senate, which would require a two-thirds majority—a bar that is all the higher because of the way partisanship has intensified since Watergate. And so the operative questions in weighing the evidence placed before America by Mr Mueller’s digging are not just what did the president know and when did he know it—but also what are voters and Republican elected officials willing to tolerate in the name of partisan advantage.

The fog of law

Before getting to that, however, comes the most basic question of all: what did Mr Trump do? He has repeatedly called Mr Mueller’s investigation a “witch hunt”, the phrase Nixon used about the investigation into Watergate. In fact Mr Mueller has hewed closely to the terms of his appointment, which were to investigate “any links and/or co-ordination” between Russia’s government and the Trump campaign, as well as “any matters that arose or may arise directly from the investigation”. Mr Trump has repeatedly insisted that the investigation shows “no collusion”, by which he seems to mean some sort of direct evidence of him accepting demands or enticements from Vladimir Putin or someone who works for him.

But that misconstrues what Mr Mueller’s task was. He conducted a counterintelligence investigation, not a criminal probe. Sometimes such investigations produce evidence of criminal activity. And sometimes that activity is prosecuted, depending on what investigators wish to reveal about what they know and how they know it. Or it may be overlooked to protect intelligence sources and methods. The public will probably never know all that Mr Mueller’s team does, because that would inevitably reveal how he came to know it, and so choke off future sources of intelligence.

Mr Mueller has outlined how one part of Russia’s influence operation worked in a pair of indictments—one against 13 Russian citizens and three companies and another against 12 agents of the GRU (Russia’s military-intelligence service). Beginning in 2014, the 13 citizens—working for the Internet Research Agency, a Russian Internet-troll farm funded by a businessman with close ties to Mr Putin—began setting up fake social-media pages and travelling to America to collect intelligence and rent American computer infrastructure to disguise their Russian origins. Their activities ramped up as the election drew closer. Online, they played all sides—posing as Muslims, immigration hardliners, supporters of Black Lives Matter and others—and were instructed to “use any opportunity to criticise Hillary and the rest (except Trump and Sanders—we support them).”

In this effort, Vladimir Putin was not a spymaster sitting at the centre of a vast web, tugging each strand in turn to produce the perfect result. He was a gambler placing small bets with little risk—and he ended up with a huge payout. Those bets succeeded largely because of the character and judgment of Mr Trump and the people with whom he chose to surround himself.

The GRU agents did their work from Russia, hacking and spearphishing their way into the networks of the DNC, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) and members of Hillary Clinton’s campaign staff in order to steal emails and implant malware. Using monikers including DCLeaks and Guccifer 2.0, they released some of the purloined emails and documents, and transferred others to Wikileaks, which released some just before the Democrats’ convention in July 2016 and more in the month before the election. Between those two releases, the indictment alleges that Guccifer 2.0 communicated with “a person who was in regular contact with senior members” of Mr Trump’s campaign.

That person appears to have been Roger Stone, a political consultant whose official role with the campaign ended in August 2015, though he remained an ardent Trump supporter and has a longstanding relationship with the president (he first encouraged Mr Trump to run for the White House in 1988). In the indictment filed against him on January 24th, Mr Mueller alleges that he had advance knowledge of Wikileaks’ stolen material. He also alleges that after Wikileaks released its first batch of stolen documents on July 22nd, “a senior Trump campaign official was directed” to contact Mr Stone about what else Wikileaks might have, and that Mr Stone happily complied.

Mr Mueller charged Mr Stone not for communicating with a cutout for Russian intelligence, but for lying about it, tampering with witnesses and obstructing a congressional investigation. Several other subjects of Mr Mueller’s investigation have pleaded guilty to similar charges, including Michael Flynn, Mr Trump’s first national-security advisor, who admitted to lying about contacts with Russia’s ambassador before Mr Trump took office; and George Papadopoulos, a foreign-policy advisor to the Trump campaign whom a Russian cutout approached offering “dirt” on Ms Clinton’s campaign and who, until three months before Mr Trump’s election, was trying to arrange an “off the record” meeting in Moscow between campaign staff and “members of president Putin’s office” and the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

How much did Mr Trump know about all this? Michael Cohen—Mr Trump’s former lawyer, also on his way to prison for lying to Congress, as well as a suite of financial crimes—testified under oath that Donald Trump junior told his father about a meeting in Trump Tower on June 9th 2016 arranged by a Russian oligarch close to Mr Putin between campaign staff (including Paul Manafort, then the campaign chair, and Jared Kushner, Mr Trump’s son-in-law) and Russian lobbyists with links to Mr Putin and Russian intelligence. The younger Mr Trump at first said the meeting concerned the American adoption of Russian children, which Mr Putin banned when America imposed human-rights sanctions on Russia. On June 3rd Donald junior received an email from a British associate of the oligarch who arranged the meeting stating that the Russian attendees would provide “some official documents and information that would incriminate Hillary”. The younger Mr Trump’s response was “if it’s what you say I love it.”

Mr Cohen also testified that Mr Trump “knew of and directed” negotiations about building a Trump Tower in Moscow during the campaign, and both lied about it and directed Mr Cohen to lie about it. These negotiations were fruitless, and at times comical, but not for any lack of effort from Mr Trump’s inner circle. In 2015 Felix Sater, a Russian-born felon and real-estate developer, promised Mr Cohen: “I will get Putin on this program and we will get Donald elected…Buddy our boy can become president of the USA and we can engineer it. I will get all of Putin’s team to buy in on this.” After that went nowhere, Mr Cohen resorted to emailing the Kremlin’s general press inbox in an effort to reach Mr Putin’s spokesman.

The president’s own version of these events has changed a few times. On the campaign trail he said again and again that he had no deals in Russia. In January 2017, shortly before he was inaugurated, he held a press conference in which he repeated this. “I have no deals, I have no loans and I have no dealings. We could make deals in Russia very easily if we wanted to, I just don’t want to because I think that would be a conflict.” After Mr Cohen’s testimony to Congress the line changed. “We were very open with it. We were thinking about building a building. …. There would have been nothing wrong if I did do it. If I did do it, there would have been nothing wrong.”

One plausible explanation for the contacts between assorted Russians and the Trump campaign is that they were inexperienced, incurious and acquisitive, but they did not know they were conspiring with the Russian government. Yet intelligence operatives do not generally hand out business cards with a Lubyanka Square address printed under their real name. When it comes to national-security breaches, naivety is not much of a defence. Amy Berman Jackson, the judge overseeing the trials of Mr Manafort and Mr Stone, noted that a person “doesn’t have to be in the government or even be an active spy to be a link” to Russia’s government. She was referring at the time to Konstantin Kilimnik, with whom Mr Manafort shared the Trump campaign’s polling data, and who is thought to have connections to Russian intelligence. Mr Trump’s team may have been so keen to win, or to extract some financial advantage, that they considered any offer to help to be acceptable.

Thus far six people who worked on the Trump campaign have been indicted, along with 26 Russians.

And for our next trick

The completion of the Mueller report will not be the end of the president’s troubles. That is because Mr Mueller has fed a series of Congressional and judicial processes.

Start with the Congressional Democrats. After they won the House of Representatives in the midterm elections held last year, they gained control of committees, providing them with an arsenal of hearings, subpoena powers and summons to pursue the president. Under the new management, no fewer than five committees in the House have launched investigations into every aspect of Trump world. They are probing not just campaign collusion with Russia, but also the Trump Organisation, the Trump Foundation (now shut down), and the expeditious security clearances granted to the president’s family, among a lengthy list of other things. Contrary to speculation, Mr Mueller did not end his investigation with charges against any members of the Trump family. Although they will take comfort from that, the damaging details of the Mueller report map out the president’s weakest points—which the committee chairs will gleefully pound till the next election.

Congressional committees tend to retread the footsteps of a special investigation into the president. That is what happened with Watergate, with the Iran-Contra affair under Reagan and after Whitewater. The House Intelligence Committee has already investigated allegations of collusion under its previous Republican chair, Devin Nunes, and closed it after finding nothing significant. The investigation was mired in partisan dysfunction unusual for the normally staid intelligence committees (the Senate Intelligence Committee, while still under Republican control, has a similar ongoing investigation that retains bipartisan support). Mr Nunes operated more as a dogged defender of the president than as an impartial investigator. Adam Schiff, the Democrat who now runs the House Intelligence Committee, has reopened the investigation, and will keep public attention on Mr Trump’s misdeeds indefinitely.

Other committees will keep themselves busy prodding the president’s non-Russian improprieties. The House Judiciary Committee, led by Jerrold Nadler, issued a flurry of 81 letters to gather information about a variety of possible misdeeds: campaign-finance violations in paying off an adult film actress with whom Mr Trump allegedly had an affair; several instances of obstruction of justice; and enrichment from foreign powers while in office in violation of the Constitution. Elijah Cummings, who leads the House Oversight Committee, is issuing requests across similar lines—and also adding a review of security-clearances granted to Jared Kushner, the president's son-in-law, despite serious vetting concerns. Endangering the jobs of Ivanka Trump and Mr Kushner, who now occupy senior posts in the White House, is sure to enrage the president.

The last strategy for Democrats is to go after the money. Maxine Waters, the chair of the House Financial Services Committee, is in talks with Deutsche Bank, the president’s primary lender, to obtain Mr Trump’s bank records and investigate accusations of money laundering. An archaic law, written in the 1920s, gives the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee the ability to obtain the tax records of any American, including the president. As a presidential candidate, Mr Trump defied norms by not releasing his returns, and seems to have no intention of ever doing so.

Democrats sense a tantalising thicket of embarrassment: that the president paid ludicrously low amounts of tax (as the few leaked excerpts suggest); that he is not worth as much as he claims; the possibility of bank, insurance and tax fraud (as his former consigliere Michael Cohen claimed under oath in his testimony to Congress) and large, undisclosed entanglements with Saudi and Russian companies. The tax rule says that any documents furnished must be held confidentially—though they are unlikely to remain so once they arrive on Capitol Hill.

By letting many committees pursue open-ended investigations with overlapping mandates, Democrats are plainly launching as many probes as possible in the hopes of striking dirt. Republicans, especially Mr Trump, warn that this reeks of witch-hunting and risks a political backlash. Recent history suggests otherwise. Republicans employed the same strategy, only with much thinner evidence of wrongdoing, when, in an effort to embarrass Hillary Clinton, they repeatedly and fruitlessly investigated Islamist attacks in Benghazi, Libya, which killed four Americans. If there was a backlash then to the waste of taxpayer money, it was hardly noticeable.

Meanwhile, in the courthouse

Mr Mueller’s investigations have provided a trove of evidence for state and federal prosecutors. Hence, after he leaves office, Mr Trump will face legal danger from other state and federal investigations. In his home state, New York, Letitia James was elected attorney-general in November. She vowed to use “every area of the law to investigate President Trump and his business transactions and that of his family”. Her office has already dissolved the Trump Foundation, the family’s charity, accusing it of “a shocking pattern of illegality” and “functioning as little more than a checkbook to serve Mr Trump’s political and business interests”. That does not entirely settle the suit; the office wants Mr Trump and his children banned from serving on the boards of other New York charities for a decade.

Like the congressional committees, Ms James is following the money. Her office has issued subpoenas to Deutsche Bank and Investors Bank, a New Jersey-based community bank, for records related to the financing of various Trump projects, including hotels in Miami, Washington and Chicago. Those subpoenas probably stem from Mr Cohen’s testimony that Mr Trump would habitually provide false information about his wealth, lowering it for tax purposes and inflating it when he wanted a loan. The state’s insurance regulator subpoenaed the Trump Foundation’s insurance broker, after Mr Cohen testified that Mr Trump inflated his assets for insurance purposes. These New York state investigations are civil rather than criminal, but they can exact sizable financial penalties, and turn over any criminal information uncovered to prosecutors.

Yet another threat comes from the Southern District of New York, which takes a particular interest in foreign corruption and prosecuting large, complex criminal organisations and which at times appears to have worked closely with Mr Mueller. The SDNY, not Mr Mueller, obtained Mr Cohen’s guilty plea; he testified to Congress that he was “in constant contact with the Southern District of New York regarding ongoing investigations”. When asked if he knew of other illegal acts committed by Mr Trump outside the scope of his testimony, he said that he did, and that the SDNY is looking into them.

If Mr Trump inflated and deflated assets as often as Mr Cohen said he did, then false filings probably abound. That could expose Mr Trump and the Trump Organisation to charges for a range of financial crimes. And if his children were involved in any of these practices, then they too could face criminal or punishing civil consequences, even though Mr Mueller stayed his hand. SDNY prosecutors are also looking into whether foreigners illegally gave money to a pro-Trump campaign group and to Mr Trump’s inaugural committee. Some glitzy inaugural events seem to have attracted an unusual number of Russian billionaires. The committee raised a record amount of money ($107m), and spent nearly all of it, though on what is unclear. Mr Obama’s inaugural committee raised and spent about half that amount, though it hosted ten balls to Mr Trump’s three. Yet because the SDNY is a federal jurisdiction, the president could in theory pardon anyone it convicts. Whether a president can pardon himself is untested.

Mulling Mueller

When weighing the evidence against Nixon, John Doar, the counsel to the House judiciary committee, argued that it would be wrong to impeach the president for his conduct on any single day. A president could only be justifiably impeached if he repeatedly broke the law and misled the public.

The central allegation that has dogged Mr Trump is that, knowingly or not, his campaign worked with a hostile government in the hope of winning an election or making money or both. That is more serious than the bungled attempts of the committee to re-elect Nixon to gather dirt on Democrats. However, Mr Trump, despite his Twitter musings, has not used the CIA to prevent prosecutors from doing their job, used the IRS to go after his enemies or personally doctored transcripts of conversations, as Nixon did.

Gerald Ford, when he was the minority leader in the House, had a more pragmatic view. “An impeachable offence,” he said in 1970, “is whatever a majority of the House of Representatives considers it to be.” That determination depends on two things. Since impeachment requires overriding the mandate given to the president by the electorate, it should be used only if the president has broken the trust placed in him. That is a subjective judgement. In practice, the president must also be unpopular, both with his own party and with voters.

The House impeached Andrew Johnson not just because he threatened to betray the cause that the Union had fought for, but also because he was a self-regarding bore. He once managed to refer to himself 200 times in an hour-long speech. Reagan, by Contrast, survived Iran-Contra in part because his approval ratings were robust, and because the appetite in Congress and in the country for a repeat of the Watergate experience was limited.

Compared with Reagan, Mr Trump is not at all popular: his overall approval ratings hover around 40%. But among Republicans, they remain in the 90s. That affects the congressional calculus that will determine his fate. It also conditions how Republican voters view the Russia affair. One of the mind tricks performed by Mr Trump since he became the standard-bearer of the Republican Party has been to persuade many supporters that Russia is a friendly power. In 2014, when Mr Obama was president, Gallup found that 22% of Republicans thought Russia was an ally of America. By 2018 that share had risen to 40%. Only a third of Republicans think Russia interfered in the 2016 election, according to IPSOS/Reuters, despite the judgement of America’s intelligence agencies and the detailed descriptions of the GRU’s actions in Mr Mueller’s indictments.

That is not because these Republican voters have carefully weighed the evidence. They are doing what voters mostly do, which is to decide which candidate they like and then tell themselves a story that justifies their preference. The contrast with Nixon is stark. In the time between the firing of Cox and his resignation, Gallup recorded that Nixon’s approval rating among Republicans fell from 90% to 50%. That will only be of some comfort to Mr Trump, because Mr Mueller’s report may indeed contain something damaging. And even if it does not, an investigative cloud is going to colour his mood and to shape his politics.

Either way, Mr Trump’s removal by impeachment is hard to see. It would take a lot for 22 Republican senators to turn on their president. If Americans want to be rid of him, it will probably be by the ballot box in November 2020. Mr Trump has everything riding on that vote. Win and he will reshape the country in his image. Lose and he will exit, pursued by lawyers.
